titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Lady Pleasance Reeve Smith, Original Letters
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:57
profiledesc.descrules: translation missing: en.enumerations.resource_finding_aid_description_rules.beinecke manuscript unit archival processing manual

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract:
Autograph MSS.
Collection of letters assembled by Lady Smith from her correspondence and that of her husband, Sir James Edward Smith (1759-1828); before each section of letters, she provides a brief biographical sketch of the authors represented in those letters; the third volume contains mainly letters reacting to her husband's death and to her Memoir and Correspondence of the Late Sir J.E. Smith; collection touches on many aspects of the Smiths' interests, personal and public, scientific and literary; it illustrates their many friendships, especially with the family of William Roscoe (1753-1831) and the Holkham literary circle; especially interesting are the discussions of gardening and concerning the Linnean Society of England; on the whole it provides a well-rounded picture of Norfolk society and literature from the late 18th century to the mid 19th century; the collection includes several MS and printed poems.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: For provenance information, consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Osborn d148 is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Lady Pleasance Reeve Smith, Original letters. James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was produced from a previously existing list or card set. All pertinent bibliographical information has been retained; the volume may contain additional unlisted material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The following finding aid is a complete inventory of the contents of Osborn d148. This list was reformatted from previously existing cataloging.

Gardening

did.unittitle: AL (in 3rd person) to Pleasance (Reeve) Smith, Lady Smith (1773-1877)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
n.p.
3 p.; 18 x 11 cm.
Thanks her for sending a copy of the
"Memoirs of Sir James Edward Smith"
(1759-1828).
d 148/3/51

did.unittitle: 3 ALS to Pleasance (Reeve) Smith, Lady Smith (1773-1877)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
8 p.; 23 x 19 cm.
About the death and the "Memoirs" of
Sir James Edward Smith (1759-1828),
the death and career of Lord Byron
(George Gordon Noel Byron, 6th baron,
1788-1824), the writings of the
ancient author Virgil, etc.
d 148/3/11, 34, 44

1832 Nov 5 and Nov 11

"Memoirs of Sir James Edward Smith"
(1759-1828) and contemporary
reaction to the work.

various places

Burns (1759-1796) and Allan Ramsay
(1686-1758), his health, etc.

did.unittitle: 2 ALS to Pleasance (Reeve) Smith, Lady Smith (1773-1877)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[1828 Mar] and n.d.
n.p.
6 p.; 18 x 11 and 23 x 19 cm.
The first letter (148/3/8) discusses
his present health conditions and
thanks Lady Smith for having sent
him a copy of the "Memoirs of Sir
James Edward Smith" (1759-1828);
attached to this item is an extract
written by her husband about Mr.
Lombe which Lady Smith copied; the
second letter (148/3/23) sends his
respects.
d 148/3/8, 23

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1835-1858 various dates
Benhall, Sloane Street, etc.
99 p.; various sizes
About his poetry and work on Thomas
Gray (1716-1771), his friendship
with Samuel Rogers (1763-1855), Lady
Smith's memoir of her husband (Sir
James Edward Smith, 1759-1828),
literary subjects, gardening, his
travels, friends, etc.;
with 20 p.; also with 20 p.;
of poetry from the "Gentleman's
Magazine".
d 148/1/16-50; d 148/3/47

did.unittitle: "Lines to be placed under the portrait of the Rt. Revd. Dr. Henry Bathurst, Lord Bishop of Norwich [1744-1837], at Holkham:" MS copy by Pleasance (Reeve) Smith, Lady Smith (1773-1877)
1 ALS and 1 LS to Pleasance (Reeve) Smith, Lady Smith (1773-1877)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1828 Dec 16 and 1830 Feb 6
Lodge Lane
8 p.; 23 x 19 cm.
About botany, the Linnean Society
and the death of Sir James Edward
Smith (1759-1828).
One letter (148/3/22) is partly
transcribed by his son, Henry Roscoe
(1800-1836), and the other (148/3/25)
is wholly written by "T.E.R." [Thomas
Roscoe? (1791-1871)].
d 148/3/22, 25

did.unittitle: 10 ALS to Pleasance (Reeve) Smith, Lady Smith (1773-1877)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
The Cottage and Havodonus
60 p.; various sizes
Various reflections on her own works
and those of friends.
d 148/1/52-61

did.unittitle: ALS to Pleasance (Reeve) Smith, Lady Smith (1773-1877)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Gillingham Hall
5 p.; 18 x 11 and 23 x 18 cm.

"Memoirs of Sir James Edward Smith"
(1759-1828) and sends news of common

d 148/3/32

did.unittitle: 2 ALS to Pleasance (Reeve) Smith, Lady Smith (1773-1877)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1828 Sep 20 and 1833 Sep 8
6 p.; 25 x 20 cm.
The first letter (148/3/21) sends
his condolences on the death of his
uncle, Sir James Edward Smith
(1759-1828), and the second
(148/3/52) discusses the memoirs his
aunt has sent him.
d 148/3/21, 52

did.unittitle: 2 ALS to Pleasance (Reeve) Smith, Lady Smith (1773-1877)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1828 Apr 8 and n.d.
6 p.; 19 x 11 cm. and 13 x 10 cm.
The first letter (148/3/19) sends
condolences on the death of Sir
James Edward Smith (1759-1828) and
the second (148/3/46) comments on
the "Memoirs" of the late Sir James
which she had heard read.
Women Writers.
d 148/3/19, 46

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
n.p.
3 p.; 26 x 20 cm.
The introduction to the copy of
letter reads: "The following was a
portion of a letter I sent to
Professor Smyth on finding he had
introduced Dr. Priestley [Joseph
Priestley (1733-1804)] in his
Evidences as one of the defenders of
Christianity. His name having been
unjustly slandered. I was gratified
that the professor had vindicated
his injured memory."
d 148/1/65

did.unittitle:
3 ALS to Pleasance (Reeve) Smith, Lady
Smith (1773-1877)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1828 Apr 6, 1830 Mar 18, 1833 Feb 4
various places
10 p.; various sizes
The first letter (148/3/18) sends
his condolences on the death of Sir
James Edward Smith (1759-1828); the
second (148/3/26) concerns
correspondence which he has yet to
look over; and the third (148/3/45)
concerns the "Memoirs" of Sir James.
d 148/3/18, 26, 45
